reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s appeal to historical “ongoing moral catastrophes” as evidence for default-value fragility/moral blindness, arguing the same history supports moral convergence/error-correction and thus a larger ‘target’ for good futures. That line is relevant but not fully central: the position also rests on many forward-looking fragility mechanisms (population ethics, digital beings, bounded/unbounded value-function analysis, multiplicative-factor model), so even if history suggested default improvement, much of the argument could survive. Strength is moderate: pointing out underdetermination/reversal in the historical evidence does weaken that evidential support, but it doesn’t directly answer the essay’s main claim that even ‘common-sense utopia’ can miss most value due to many specific, non-obvious failure modes; showing “some moral progress happens” doesn’t establish “mostly-great futures are likely by default.” Correctness is high: it’s plausible that historical abolition/rights expansions often arose endogenously rather than explicit de dicto optimization for ‘best outcomes,’ and that this undercuts a one-directional inference from historical moral blindness to future moral catastrophe. Clarity is high and dead weight is low; it focuses on a single objection. Overall is anchored to centrality×strength (~0.18) and nudged up slightly for crispness/insight, but remains limited because it attacks only one support strand and doesn’t engage the essay’s broader, more technical case for ‘no easy eutopia.’
title: Historical moral progress suggests strong attractors toward improvement, not fragility
